content.description:
The climbing is quite straight-forward, but there is not always gear exactly where you'd like and a 5.6 leader may find protection a little sneaky. Despite this, it can be protected safely without crazy runouts.



The left of the two main wide splitters at the crag. 

Gear. Anchor is one single staple - bring a cordalette to equalize with an adjacent route's anchor.

Climb horizontal pockets up to a big ledge, then up jugs and a big crack left of a perched boulder at the top of the crag.



Start to the right of Oscar Takes a Stroll, below some obvious horizontal incuts. 

Gear. Anchor is one single staple - bring a cordalette to equalize with an adjacent route's anchor.

Interesting climbing. Despite appearances from the ground it's all there, there are many little edges and mini-jugs to take you through the upper section. I'd suggest taking your nuts. 



In the middle of the wall here is a wide hand crack that wanders off right. Climb this, but depart straight up before this crack merges into a shelf. Climb up until you are on a big ledge, stay right of the big hallow flakes (I believe these belong to Roughness). Find the mini-jugs, gear thins out up here but the holds are all there.

Single rack, including nuts. . Anchor is one single staple - bring a cordalette to equalize with an adjacent route's anchor.

Quite good climbing - hand jams and edges for the first half, then jugs when it steepens. 



The right of the two main hands splitters at the crag.

Gear to 4". Anchor is one single staple - bring a cordalette to equalize with an adjacent route's anchor.

A series of seams up the wall with good edges between. Engaging climbing that feel steep and thin but rewards you with good edges and good protection where you need it. Nutcraft helps, but you don't need to be that wily about it.



Start up Squiggles, then after a few moves transfer right into the thin broken seams. 

Small gear from a red C3 to #2, with some nuts. Anchor is one single staple - bring a cordalette to equalize with an adjacent route's anchor.

A modest south-facing crag with 11 routes ranging from 5.6 to mid-10. The two major landmarks are the two central easy-looking handcracks in the middle - the left one is Doodles (5.6) and the right one is Squiggles (5.7).  Despite appearances the climbing is actually kind of interesting, though often the placements are a little technical so bring your stoppers. 

The experience is currently marred by the anchors, which comprise of a single rock staple atop each route. I recommend bringing a cordalette to equalize between adjacent rock staples, but as for cleaning routes you're on your own.
